PREVIEW: MAS expected to tighten FX-based policy today & Singapore GDP figures due at 0100BST/1900CDT
content:
The Monetary Authority of Singapore is expected to tighten policy at its semi-annual policy announcement today with 12 out of 19 analysts surveyed forecasting the central bank to slightly increase the appreciation rate or slope of the SGD Nominal Effective Exchange Rate from the current 0%. However, calls are nowhere near one-sided with the remaining analysts or 37% of total respondents advocating for no policy changes.

As a guide, the MAS utilizes the exchange rate as its main policy tool in which it could tweak policy through either the mid-point, slope or width of the currency band. For example, the MAS could alter the mid-point of its SGD NEER band which if lowered, would effectively be easing policy by weakening the SGD against a basket of currencies. The central bank could also alter the slope of the trading band to adjust the path of the currency, or widen the width of the trading band which would be seen as a neutral measure but would allow the currency more room to fluctuate.

Expectations for a tighter policy stance have been supported by stronger growth as Singapore's economy expanded by 3.6% in 2017 vs. 2.4% in 2016, while improvement in the labour market and likely unwillingness to fall behind the curve are among the reasons being cited to likely spur a move from the MAS. In addition, there was a slight tweak in the central bank's statement in the last announcement 6 months ago which stated 'MAS had indicated in the October 2016 MPS that the neutral policy stance would be appropriate for an extended period' vs. the April language that 'as indicated in the October 2016 MPS, a neutral policy stance is appropriate for an extended period'. As such, some have suggested the change in statement was to likely pave the way for possible tightening this year.

Conversely, ongoing trade uncertainties from increased protectionist stances and MAS anticipation of subdued price pressures could encourage the MAS to keep its neutral stance. Furthermore, a firmer currency against the greenback with USD/SGD currently below 1.3100 vs. around 1.3600 during the last meeting could also support calls for the central bank to hold off on tightening its FX-based monetary policy

Today's announcement is due at 0100BST/1900CDT and will coincide with the release of Advanced GDP figures for Q1 (Q/Q Exp. 1.2%, Prev. 2.1%; Y/Y Exp. 4.3% Prev. 3.6%) although focus is likely to be centred on the policy announcement.

MARKET RECAP

US equity futures traded higher with sentiment boosted in the morning by US President Trump’s tweets, which put some Syrian tensions to ease. Futures also jumped at the US cash open and carried on the upward trend for most of the session, until reports suggested that the US is planning to strike eight targets in Syria (however this was never officially confirmed) and the markets resumed the buying trend. The S&P was led by Incyte (INCY) and MGM Resorts (MGM), INCY were upgraded to buy from neutral at UBS, and MGM were supported by reports from WSJ that it is in early talks to purchase Wynn Resorts’ (WYNN) Boston-area Casino Project. L-Brands (LB) lagged as the company’s PINK brand’s saw sales fall in March. McDonald’s (MCD) hampered the DJI today following reports which suggested workers in Kentucky may have spread Hepatitis A to some customers; and on the flip side, Intel (INTC) and Boeing (BA) led the DJI. In M&A news, Takeda (4502 JT) reportedly seeks several trillions of JPY worth of loans as it looks to acquire Shire (SHPG) which closed among the best performers in NDX. Also, General Electric (GE) are considering merging its units with other public companies, or an IPO or spinoff of its Transportation unit, as an alternative to asset sales. Later trade today saw rumours that Warren Buffet’s Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) was reportedly ready to make an announcement for the takeover of Southwest Airlines (LUV), which gave a boost to all airline names, which finished trade well in the green, however these reports were unconfirmed. On earnings front today also saw Blackrock (BLK) beating on both the top and bottom line sending them to close higher than 1.5%, combined with the higher yields today led to financials outperforming which finished Thursday trade higher by 2%. Delta earnings beat expectations, posting record revenues in the face of strong demand, though fuel and labour costs were rising. On Friday, JPM, Wells Fargo and Citi report numbers before the market open. JPM expected to report 2.28 eps on 27.7bln of revenue, Wells expected to report 1.06 eps on 21.7bln, and Citi expected to report 1.61 eps on revenues of 18.9bln. SPX +0.83% at 2664, NDX +1.11% at 6656 , DJI +1.21% at 24483.

US Treasury yields were higher on Thursday with short-dated yields up by 4bps and long-end yields up around 5bps by settlement, although most of the selling was in the belly of the curve. Selling pressure was seen pre-market after Trump’s tweet hinted that military action might not be in the offing. Even later in the session, when it emerged the US was close to military action, the Treasury complex struggled to catch a bid. The US completed this week’s supply offering with an auction of 30-year bonds, which stopped through the screens by 0.1bps, the strongest auction this week. Traders were encouraged by the direct bidders after the weakness seen this week, while indirects took down 61%, in line with recent averages. US 10yr T-Notes settle 12 ticks lower at 120-15.

US MARKET WRAP 12 April 2018: Risk on as geopolitical fears abate
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Stocks up, USD up, treasuries lower, oil higher
* REAR-VIEW: Geopolitical tensions re-emerge, Dovish ECB Minutes, US earnings season begins
* AHEAD: Fedspeak (on Friday Kaplan, Bullard, Rosengren), ECB speak (Draghi on Friday), Summit of Americas, US bank numbers (JPM, WFC, C)

* GEOPOLITICS: The session began on the front foot, as Trump’s tweets stating that an attack on Syria could be ‘soon or not so soon at all’ eased fears of an imminent strike in Syria. However, the tone reversed in later trade, after sources reported that the US is planning to strike eight targets in Syria which led risk-aversion to temporarily return in the market. Trump is meeting with US officials tonight, and there is an expectation that military action could be announced imminently. US officials also confirmed evidence of chemical weapons from victims involved in the chemical attack in Syria. Finally, in late trade, Russia requested a UN security council meeting on Syria.

* TRADE WARS: Further positive comments on the NAFTA front were seen today, with US President Trump noting there is not a set timeline for talks, but he is confident a deal is close, and it could take weeks or months as negotiations are "coming along great”. US Trade Representative Lighthizer and Republican Senator Cornyn have both echoed Trump’s language adding some positivity on the proximity of an agreement, alongside which Ambassador to Canada Kelly Craft added the countries are working towards a modern pact. Separately, the USTR said to have lowered regional value content demand for NAFTA cars to 75%, while the Times reported that Canadian PM Trudeau is confident US will not put a steel tariff on Canada.

* ECB Accounts from March Meeting noted widespread concerns about the potential impact of trade wars. Policymakers said FX is a source of uncertainty, though past appreciation has not had a marked impact on demand, and euro strength was not fully due to macro environment, and may have a more negative impact on inflation. Policymakers also said gradual communication adjustments are required, inflation path close to sustained adjustment, but majority say it is not sufficient. It also said that monetary support still required after the end of bond purchases. Reaction was muted.

* ECB SPEAK: ECB's Coeure said current monetary policy position is appropriate, and that the outlook for productivity growth may be less concerning than current figures suggest. Coeure also said that the possibility of larger-than-estimated slack does not mean that monetary policy will have to remain unchanged, while he also expects the central bank's key rates will remain at their present levels for an extended period of time, in line with ECB's current guidance. Elsewhere, the ECB's Weidmann said price stability goal must not be weakened.

* BANXICO: Mexico holds rates at 7.50%, as expected; unanimous decision. Banxico also notes that balance of risks to growth is on the downside, but upward bias in inflation. Crucially, it noted that NAFTA risks had recently eased slightly. There was no reaction in the peso.

* EQUITIES: SPX +0.83% at 2664, NDX +1.11% at 6656 , DJI +1.21% at 24483  SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): +0.45%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): -0.19%, ENERGY (XLE): -0.01%, FINANCIALS (XLF): +1.82%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): +0.64%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): +1.45%, MATERIALS (XLB): +1.07%, TECH (XLK): +1.29%, TELECOMS (XTL): -0.03%, UTLITIES (XLU): -1.28%.  US equity futures traded higher on Thursday trade, boosted in the morning by US President Trump’s tweets, which put some Syrian tensions to ease. Futures also jumped at the US cash open and carried on the upward trend for most of the session, until reports suggested that the US is planning to strike eight targets in Syria (however this was never officially confirmed) and the markets resumed the buying trend. The S&P was led by Incyte (INCY) and MGM Resorts (MGM), INCY were upgraded to buy from neutral at UBS, and MGM were supported by reports from WSJ that it is in early talks to purchase Wynn Resorts’ (WYNN) Boston-area Casino Project. L-Brands (LB) lagged as the company’s PINK brand’s saw sales fall in March. McDonald’s (MCD) hampered the DJI today following reports which suggested workers in Kentucky may have spread Hepatitis A to some customers; and on the flip side, Intel (INTC) and Boeing (BA) led the DJI. In M&A news, Takeda (4502 JT) reportedly seeks several trillions of JPY worth of loans as it looks to acquire Shire (SHPG) which closed among the best performers in NDX. Also, General Electric (GE) are considering merging its units with other public companies, or an IPO or spinoff of its Transportation unit, as an alternative to asset sales. Later trade today saw rumours that Warren Buffet’s Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) was reportedly ready to make an announcement for the takeover of Southwest Airlines (LUV), which gave a boost to all airline names, which finished trade well in the green, however these reports were unconfirmed. On earnings front today also saw Blackrock (BLK) beating on both the top and bottom line sending them to close higher than 1.5%, combined with the higher yields today led to financials outperforming which finished Thursday trade higher by 2%. Delta earnings beat expectations, posting record revenues in the face of strong demand, though fuel and labour costs were rising. On Friday, JPM, Wells Fargo and Citi report numbers before the market open. JPM expected to report 2.28 eps on 27.7bln of revenue, Wells expected to report 1.06 eps on 21.7bln, and Citi expected to report 1.61 eps on revenues of 18.9bln.

* CRUDE: WTI (May) settles 25 cents higher at USD 67.07 per barrel and Brent (June) settles down 4 cents at USD 72.02 per barrel. The geopolitical pressure contained in crude prices was unwound slightly on Thursday, helped along by cryptic Trump tweets that were interpreted as constructive for risk. However, that geopolitical risk premium began re-entering crude prices in the US afternoon, after suggestions that US military action in Syria was likely to be forthcoming. Elsewhere, OPEC upped its global oil demand view for 2018; the cartel also said OPEC crude production decreased 201k bpd in March to average 31.96mln bpd, according to secondary sources. OPEC Sec Gen Barkindo said OPEC compliance was over 150% in March, and over 120% for non-OPEC members; Barkindo added that longer-term alliance between OPEC/Non-OPEC will be discussed in June, and he is confident that the supply cut deal will be extended beyond 2018, and he sees oil market rebalancing in Q2/Q3 2018 (previous saw it rebalancing by end-2018). Analysts were also updating their forecasts on Thursday; Barclays now raised its Brent and WTI forecasts by $3 to $63/bbl and $58/bbl respectively. Goldman Sachs, meanwhile, cut its crude forecast for WTI and Brent to $70.60/bbl and $75.51/bbl respectively (against a previous of $72.50/bbl and $77.50/bbl).

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes settle 12 ticks lower at 120-15. US Treasury yields were higher on Thursday with short-dated yields up by 4bps and long-end yields up around 5bps by settlement, although most of the selling was in the belly of the curve. Selling pressure was seen pre-market after Trump’s tweet hinted that military action might not be in the offing. Even later in the session, when it emerged the US was close to military action, the Treasury complex struggled to catch a bid. The US completed this week’s supply offering with an auction of 30-year bonds, which stopped through the screens by 0.1bps, the strongest auction this week. Traders were encouraged by the direct bidders after the weakness seen this week, while indirects took down 61%, in line with recent averages.

* FOREX: DXY on a firmer footing and not far from 90.000, with initial relatively limited upside seen on hawkish elements of the March FOMC minutes on Wednesday, but more momentum building after US President Trump’s tweets about Syria that suggested less urgency in terms of the timing of any military action; however, gains were slightly pared in later trade after it became clear that US military action may still be imminent. CAD/EUR/JPY/CHF all victims of broad Greenback recovery to an extent, with USDCAD hovering either side of the 1.2600 figure in late trade; the Loonie was also undermined by weaker than expected Canadian house price data. EURUSD failed or faded again just ahead of 1.24, and then recoiled to test bids/support at the big figure below in wake of dovish/cautious ECB minutes that highlight policy divergence from not just the Fed, but BoE too, and EURGBP finally breached 0.8700 to the downside before triggering stops through 0.8690 on its way down to circa 0.8665. USDJPY held just under well documented big 107.00 option strikes prior to Trump and then cleared the key level and absorbed at least some reported export offers ahead of recent highs that also align with the next upside pivot around 107.50-55.  GBP/NZD/AUD: Bucking the overall trend or at least holding up better than G10 counterparts, with Cable rebounding to 1.42 again amidst talk of real money and sovereign buying interest on dips. NZD faded from best levels close to 0.7400, but kept ahead of AUD as the cross pivoted around 1.0500 and AUDUSD slipped under 0.7750.

AUCTION PREVIEW: US to sell USD 13bln 30-year bonds on Thursday 12th April 2018 at 1800BST (1300 eastern time)
content:
The US Treasury will auction USD 62bln in 3-year notes (USD 30bln, Tuesday), 10-year bonds ($21bln, Wednesday) and 30-year bonds ($13bln, Thursday). With a total of USD 76.5bln maturing at mid-month settlement, the auction will actually pay down USD 12.5bln in the week.

The previous 30-year auction mixed, stopping through the WI by half a basis point at the bidding deadline but demand was soft as the auction was only covered 2.38x vs. six-auction average of 2.44x. However, five of the last six auctions have stopped through the WI at the bidding deadline with February the outlier (1.3bps tail).

TD Securities are more cautious on the 30-year bond offering than they were the 10s and 3s. “The flattening in the 5s30s and 10s30s curves has recently stopped, and we suspect that investors may not be overly keen to drive the curve flatter in the near-term.”

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Dollar derives more from latest Trump tweet than hawkish Fed tweak
content:
DXY

Ending the session on a firmer footing and not far from 90.000, with initial relatively limited upside seen on hawkish elements of the March FOMC minutes, but more momentum building after US President Trump’s latest tweet about Syria that suggested less urgency in terms of the timing of any military action.

CAD/EUR/JPY/CHF

All net losers and victims of the broad Greenback recovery to an extent, with Usd/Cad back over 1.2600 and the Loonie also undermined by weaker than expected Canadian house price data. Eur/Usd failed or faded again just ahead of 1.2400, and then recoiled to test bids/support at the big figure below in wake of dovish/cautious ECB minutes that highlight policy divergence from not just the Fed, but BoE too, and Eur/Gbp finally breached 0.8700 to the downside before triggering stops through 0.8690 on its way down to circa 0.8665. Usd/Jpy held just under well documented big 107.00 option strikes prior to Trump and then cleared the key level and absorbed at least some reported export offers ahead of recent highs that also align with the next upside pivot around 107.50-55.  Usd/Chf relatively bid throughout, but extended gains to almost 0.9650 and not much further from the 200 DMA (0.9668).

GBP/NZD/AUD

Bucking the overall trend or at least holding up better than G10 counterparts, with Cable rebounding to 1.4200 again amidst talk of real money and sovereign buying interest on dips. Nzd/Usd faded from best levels close to 0.7400, but kept ahead of Aud as the cross pivoted around 1.0500 and Aud/Usd slipped under 0.7750.

SEK/NOK

Contrasting fortunes for the Scandi currencies, as Eur/Sek spiked on softer than expected Swedish inflation and house price updates, but Eur/Nok retreated further from post sub-consensus Norwegian CPI peaks following more Norges Bank guidance via Governor Olsen for a post-Summer hike.

subject: FIXED AND FX LATEST: divergence and decoupling after mixed US data
content: Not much to glean from the latest batch of US macro leads that were rather contrasting vs consensus and as such did provide any clear direction. However, cautious/dovish ECB minutes underscored the difference between policy gears with the Fed and to a lesser degree BoE, to leave Bunds off worst levels vs Gilts and US Treasuries slipping to fresh lows for the day. Meanwhile in FX, the Dollar is bid overall and against most major rivals as Eur/Usd retreats towards 1.2300 and Usd/Jpy nudges up near recent peaks circa 107.50, but losing more ground against the like of the Rub and Try on less risk aversion and front-running intervention.

EU DEBT UPDATE: multiple factors behind push or shove to new session lows
content: Several negative/bearish impulses have prompted another downturn in fixed, and yet again it appears that the US President has trumped the lot via a more non-committal and less confrontational tweet on Syria (suggesting a strike is not imminent). BTPs succumbed to some post-auction selling with investors perhaps showing a degree of political reservation ahead of the next round of talks in Italy to try and form a coalition government. Looking at Bunds, 159.22 marks the fresh low (-28 ticks), with stops and short term charts supports also exacerbating the retreat no doubt, while Gilts have been as low as 122.16 (-40 ticks) and USTs have erased all overnight recovery gains and flipped to a steeper trajectory (very early long bond sale concession?). More immediately, ECB minutes to provide additional direction.

subject: UBS examines FX that might be impacted by Syria strikes
content:
• FX has largely ignored Syria news with the exception of a few currencies. 
  • In 2017, the currencies most impacted were ZAR, SEK, KRW, EUR and TRY, but this time most noticeable impacted assets are RUB, TRY, CAD and gold.
  • Implies that the FX market has for the most part discounted the threat of missile strikes except with concerns that the fallout will be bad for Russia. TRY gets dragged into it due to the close ties with Russia.
  • UBS says if your view is that the rhetoric will ease and this will be one more event blown out of proportion, weaker CAD or Gold are the trades to look at, adding that cash trades are probably better as, currently, options don’t offer good enough risk reward.
  • UBS says if you believe this tension could extend further, look for a USDCHF lower move as the pair hasn’t reacted to the news yet, at this stage.

  • Equity markets treading water as markets await any firm action in Syria
  • Mild USD strength following Wednesday’s slightly hawkish FOMC Minutes
  • Looking ahead ECB minutes, US weekly jobs, BoE’s Carney, ECB’s Weidmann, Constancio, Fed’s Kashkari

ASIA

Asia equity markets traded subdued after a negative lead from US with sentiment dampened amid heightened geopolitical tensions after US President Trump warned that missiles will be coming to Syria, while markets also digested a more hawkish tone in the FOMC minutes which stated that a number of policymakers suggested the economic outlook implies a steeper rise in Fed Funds Rate over the next few years than previously expected. This saw a lacklustre tone for ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.3%), although losses were contained as fears of an imminent strike on Syria abated with the White House National Security Council to meet on Thursday afternoon to decide on its response. Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) also conformed to the overall gloom after the PBoC skipped liquidity operations again and amid weakness in Shanghai metals trade, while Hang Seng (+0.3%) initially bucked the trend as blue-chip energy stocks were underpinned after geopolitical concerns buoyed oil prices but then gradually fell in-line with its peers. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful despite the weakness in Japanese stocks and after a 30yr auction was also ignored despite showing higher b/c and accepted prices than prior.

PBoC skips open market operations again today. (Newswires)

PBoC sets CNY mid-point at 6.2834 (Prev. 6.2911). (Newswires)

BoJ Governor Kuroda said will maintain QQE w/ YCC for as long as necessary to reach 2% target in stable manner, adds will adjust policy as needed to maintain momentum towards price target & will keep increasing monetary base till inflation stably tops 2%. (Newswires)

TRADE WARS

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said China has previously made promises and not delivered but adds that President Xi's speech is a positive development. (Newswires)

China MOFCOM said China opening up is its own voluntary act and is not relevant to the trade dispute with US, while it adds that China will retaliate without hesitation if US escalates trade dispute. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

RBNZ Assistant Governor McDermott said inclusion of employment into mandate will help flexibility of inflation targeting. (Newswires)

Norges Bank's Olsen says the first increase in the key policy rate is drawing closer; reiterating that rates will rise after the summer. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

US Secretary of State nominee Pompeo is to tell senators that years of soft policy stance regarding Russia are now over, according to a source. (AP)

Russia's Kremlin states that the US and Russia are using a 'de-confliction' telephone line regarding Syria but there are currently no plans for a Trump-Putin call. (Newswires)

Syria's Assad said any action by western states will only cause more instability in the region. (State TV)

EU/UK/US

UK Brexit Secretary Davis states that a 'big upside' of Brexit will be the UK leaving the Customs Union. This is at odds with a previous report suggesting that officials could be looking to keep the UK in the Customs Union given the potential disadvantages of leaving. (WSJ/Newswires)

German economy ministry says economic upswing continues but at a slightly weaker pace, adds consumer demand has been less dynamic, but trading sentiment remains optimistic. (Newswires)

Eurozone Industrial Production MM (Feb) -0.8% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. -1.0%, Rev. -0.6%). (Newswires)

Swedish CPI YY (Mar) 1.9% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 1.6%). (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities are trading mixed in early trade, with traders awaiting any clarity on the Syria situation. As such, with little in the way of broad price action across the major indices, a bulk of the focus has fallen upon individual movers with Carrefour (-5.6%) softer after releasing uninspiring financial results for Q1. Shire (+2.8%) shares are higher amid reports that Takeda is seeking several JPY trillion worth of loans as it seeks to acquire the Co. Additionally, Volkswagen (+1.5%) have been supported after announcing their plan to IPO their trucks division in Q1 2019, alongside news that the automaker plans a management board seat for workers.

FX

In FX, the broad USD and Index has derived a degree of underlying support from more hawkish tones within the latest FOMC minutes. NZD continues to fly and outpace its antipodean peer with the cross seriously testing support around 1.0500 and a major downside technical area just below (1.0494-83 represents a 3 year rising trendline on some charts). NZD/USD is edging closer to 0.7400, while AUD/USD is still encountering resistance ahead of heavy supply at 0.7790, although a high profile US bank has gone long via a technical trade, targeting 0.7915-90 and perhaps even 0.8100. SEK, like its Scandi neighbour yesterday undermined by softer than forecast inflation data on balance, albeit with the underlying Swedish CPIF measure back to the Riksbank’s 2% objective and likely to keep rate hike prospects by the end of 2018 intact. EUR/SEK currently around the top of a 10.3770-2950 range. GBP/EUR/JPY seeing hardly any movement vs the USD, with Cable capped just below 1.4200 amidst a raft of headlines from UK Brexit Minister Davis, but nothing new on transition deal terms ahead of a speech from BoE Governor Carney later. EUR/USD still not really threatening 1.2400 offers and looking for independent impetus from ECB policy minutes after mixed messages of late. Note also, hefty option expiry interest at 1.2345 today (1.2 bn) could be exerting a downward pull. USD/JPY also caught between big expiry-related flow at 107.00 and bearish impulses due to Syria, trade and more general geopolitical/global tensions. CAD and CHF are the current G10 laggards or relative underperformers with the Loonie unwinding some NAFTA and oil inspired gains to trade back circa 1.2600 vs the USD, and Franc still trending lower vs the USD and EUR amidst the suspicion of official selling to curb and safe-haven demand.

FIXED INCOME

Not much upside momentum in Bunds on the back of a pretty bad Eurozone ip data miss, which in truth was on the cards after sub-forecast releases from several member states. However, Bunds have ticked up again following a retreat to marginal news Eurex lows at 159.35 alongside Gilts that are paring losses from -15 ticks at one stage. In the Eurozone periphery, some post auction fall out in BTPs was observed but the 10y future is now paring losses. Meanwhile, US Treasuries are a few ticks off overnight lows amidst yet more curve steepening as the Fed appears to have adopted a more aggressive view on rates, albeit a certain faction of the FOMC policy panel. On the data front, weekly claims may garner more attention than normal and last Friday’s disappointing NFP headline print, while 30 year supply could warrant a bit more concession given tepid 3 and 10 year results. But the central focus is Syria (with US-China and global trade wars rather side-lined for the moment) ahead of UK an US meetings to discuss whether a strike is the only option.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent crude futures trade relatively flat and in close proximity to recent highs as prices retain their geopolitical risk premium. This comes as traders await any updates on the Syrian situation with the White House National Security Council due to meet later today and decide their response. The UK will also be carrying out an equivalent meeting with the latest reports suggesting that UK submarines are within range for strikes on Syria which could begin as soon as tonight. This comes amid reports that Russia is anticipating information on the US’ Syrian targets and is said to be getting countermeasures ready. In metals markets, spot gold continues to linger in modest negative territory amid the fallout of the slightly more hawkish than anticipated FOMC release last night. Elsewhere,  copper mirrored the subdued risk tone overnight and was pressured in tandem with weakness in Shanghai metals trade, whilst Palladium prices continue to move higher amid the fallout of Russian sanctions.

subject: Nordea on Swedish CPI: CPIF-inflation stood at 2.0% in March, well in line with our and the Riksbank’s forecast
content:
• CPIF ex energy came in at 1.54%, which is 0.3% points below the Riksbank’s view.
  • Instant view on details: Somewhat lower prices on clothes and footwear than we thought.

12th April 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets traded subdued after a negative lead from US with sentiment dampened amid heightened geopolitical tensions after US President Trump warned that missiles will be coming to Syria, while markets also digested a more hawkish tone in the FOMC minutes which stated that a number of policymakers suggested the economic outlook implies a steeper rise in Fed Funds Rate over the next few years than previously expected. This saw a lacklustre tone for ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.3%), although losses were contained as fears of an imminent strike on Syria abated with the White House National Security Council to meet on Thursday afternoon to decide on its response. Shanghai Comp. A quiet overnight session was shaken to life after US President Trump’s pre-market tweeting, where he talked-up the possibility of military action in the Middle East, sending futures sharply lower. subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: There was little by way of an immediate reaction for the FOMC minutes, however, as the dust settled, traders latched-on to the more hawkish headlines
content:
• There was little by way of an immediate reaction for the FOMC minutes, however, as the dust settled, traders latched-on to the more hawkish headlines
  • Asian equity markets traded subdued after a negative lead from US with sentiment dampened amid heightened geopolitical tensions
  • Looking ahead, highlights include ECB minutes, US weekly jobs, BoE’s Carney, Broadbent, ECB’s Weidmann, Constancio, Fed’s Kashkari

FOMC MINUTES

FOMC minutes stated that further policy tightening is likely warranted and almost all agreed a gradual approach was appropriate, while several said future Fed’s Fund Rate will likely need to be above its longer-run normal value for a time.

All policymakers agreed that economic outlook has improved in the recent months, while a number of policymakers said economic outlook implies steeper rise in Fed funds rate over the next few years than previously expected.

All expected 1-year inflation to rise in coming month but noted the increase would not by itself justify a change in projected path, while many policymakers said they were confident that inflation would rise to target and stabilise around that level.

Some policymakers said future Fed statements may need to signal that policy will shift to a neutral or restraining factor for the economy, while a majority of policymakers view the retaliatory tariffs by other countries a downside risk for US.

There was little by way of an immediate reaction, however, as the dust settled, traders latched-on to the more hawkish headlines, specifically, “several” policy makers arguing that the future fed’s fund rate will likely need to be above its longer-run normal value for a time and also future FOMC statements may need to signal that policy will shift to a neutral or restraining factor for the economy. The USD moved towards session highs against the EUR, with EUR/USD falling from 1.2370 to around 1.2350 and USD/JPY rose above 107.00 from around 106.85, while moves along the Treasury curve were more muted, though the bias was for slightly higher yields.
 

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded subdued after a negative lead from US with sentiment dampened amid heightened geopolitical tensions after US President Trump warned that missiles will be coming to Syria, while markets also digested a more hawkish tone in the FOMC minutes. This saw a lacklustre tone for ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.3%), although losses were contained as fears of an imminent strike on Syria abated with the White House National Security Council to meet on Thursday afternoon to decide on its response. Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) also conformed to the overall gloom after the PBoC skipped liquidity operations again and amid weakness in Shanghai metals trade, while Hang Seng (+0.3%) initially bucked the trend as blue-chip energy stocks were underpinned after geopolitical concerns buoyed oil prices but then gradually fell in-line with its peers. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful despite the weakness in Japanese stocks and after a 30yr auction was also ignored despite showing higher b/c and accepted prices than prior.

PBoC skipped open market operations. PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.2834 (Prev. 6.2911)

China MOFCOM said China opening up is its own voluntary act and is not relevant to the trade dispute with US, while it added that China will retaliate without hesitation if US escalates trade dispute. (Newswires)

World Bank raised 2018 China GDP growth forecast to 6.5% from 6.4% and raised developing Asia Pacific growth forecast to 6.3% from 6.2%. (Newswires)

Bank of Korea kept the 7-Day Repo Rate unchanged at 1.50% as expected. BoK said South Korean economy and exports are to sustain growth and that consumption will recover steadily. However, the BoK also stated that investment will slow and that inflation this year will be slightly below forecasts made in January. (Newswires)


UK/EU

UK RICS Housing Survey (Mar) 0% vs. Exp. 2% (Prev. 0%). (Newswires)

British Chambers of Commerce said domestic demand remains muted and that growth is being led by the global environment. (Newswires)

Analysis suggests that UK PM May’s officials could be looking at an approach to keep the UK in the customs union given the potential disadvantages posed by leaving the union. The piece goes on to say that the narrow referendum result and general election suggests that the UK PM does not have a mandate for a hard Brexit. (Newswires)  

Italian official said the League's Salvini may be asked to form a government next week. (Newswires)


FX

The greenback attempted to nurse recent losses with DXY briefly supported from a hawkish FOMC minutes. This saw a pullback in the greenback’s major counterparts with GBP/USD on retreat from resistance just shy of the 1.4200 handle, while AUD/USD traded indecisive as support from higher oil prices was counterbalanced by weakness across the metals complex. Elsewhere, USD/JPY languished below the 107.00 handle, while HKD briefly touched the weakest point of the trading band against USD at 7.85 for the first time which if maintained, would obligate HKMA to intervene in the FX market and buy HKD.

Australian Home Loans (Feb) M/M -0.2% vs. Exp. -0.4% (Prev. -1.1%). (Newswires)
Australian Invest Housing Finance (Feb) M/M 0.5% (Prev. 1.1%)
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed in which WTI crude futures extended on its geopolitically-fuelled advances and broke above the USD 67/bbl level, as the ongoing tension in the Middle-East raise supply disruptions risks. Elsewhere, gold prices pulled-back following a hawkish FOMC minutes release, while copper mirrored the subdued risk tone and was pressured in tandem with weakness in Shanghai metals trade.

GEOPOLITICAL

White House National Security Council are to meet Thursday afternoon to decide on Syria response, according to sources. (CNN) Note: There were initial reports that US President Trump was to make a decision regarding Syria on Wednesday night. (24live)

UK was reportedly moving submarines within range of Syria for strikes which could begin as soon as Thursday night, although reports added that UK PM May has not yet reached a final decision on whether to join any airstrikes. (Telegraph) In addition, the cabinet will meet on Thursday and UK PM May is expected to ask approval for UK participation in action against Syrian chemical weapons infrastructure. (Sky News)

Russia is said to be anticipating information on US Syria targets and is said to be getting countermeasures, according to press reports. (Newswires)

US Secretary of State nominee Pompeo is to inform senators that years of soft policy stance regarding Russia are now over and is to tell senators that war is always last resort in testimony, according to sources. (Associated Press)


US

In spite of geopolitical risks spooking traders, lending a bid to some haven assets, the Treasury complex was only slightly higher on the day, with the curve modestly bull-flattening, and major curve spreads narrowed once again (5s30s at 38bps now, while 2s30s slipped by nearly 3bps to 68bps). There was some knee-jerk buying of Treasuries as US President Trump ramped-up the rhetoric, telling Russia to ‘expect missiles’ in Syria, and the buying pushed 30-year yields to beneath the 3.00% handle, while 10s visited 2.75%. The Treasury’s 10-year auction was soft, seeing a tail of 0.5bps (recent averages suggested it would come in on the screws).  The internals were grim, with indirect participation the lowest since January 2015, leaving directs and dealers with participation above recent averages. The soft auction had surprised a few analysts, particularly amid demand for haven assets today, as the US prepares military action in Syria. US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 2+ ticks higher at 120-27.

Goldman Sachs updated its Fed forecast in which it sees a hike in June more likely now and puts the probability of such a move at 85%. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades lacklustre after Wall St losses, geopolitical concerns and hawkish FOMC minutes
content:
Asia equity markets trade subdued after a negative lead from US with sentiment dampened amid heightened geopolitical tensions after US President Trump warned that missiles will be coming to Syria, while markets also digest a more hawkish tone in the FOMC minutes which stated that a number of policymakers said the economic outlook implies a steeper rise in Fed Funds Rate over the next few years than previously expected. This has resulted to a lacklustre tone for ASX 200 (-0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (Unch), although losses are contained as fears of an imminent strike on Syria have since abated with the White House National Security Council to meet on Thursday afternoon to decide on its response. Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) also conforms to the overall gloom after the PBoC skipped liquidity operations again and amid weakness in Shanghai metals trade, while Hang Seng (+0.5%) bucks the trend with blue chip energy stocks underpinned after geopolitical concerns buoyed oil prices.

In FX markets, the greenback attempted to nurse recent losses with DXY briefly supported from a hawkish FOMC minutes in which all members saw higher inflation and GDP, while several advocated that the future Fed’s Fund Rate will likely need to be above its longer-run normal value for a time and that future FOMC statements may need to signal that policy will shift to a neutral or restraining factor for the economy. This saw a pullback in the greenback’s major counterparts with GBP/USD meeting resistance just shy of the 1.4200 handle, while AUD/USD is indecisive as support from higher oil prices is counterbalanced by weakness across the metals complex. Elsewhere, USD/JPY is choppy below the 107.00 handle, while HKD briefly touched the weakest point of the trading band against USD at 7.85 for the first time in which the HKMA is obligated to intervene in the FX market and buy HKD.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are uneventful alongside an indecisive tone for Japanese stocks and with participants awaiting a 30yr auction later.
